newsitem.title: USA: U.S. Plains fed cattle sell $64.00-$64.25-feedlots.
newsitem.headline: U.S. Plains fed cattle sell $64.00-$64.25-feedlots.

text.p: U.S. Plains feedlot cattle Thursday sold mostly at $64.00 per cwt in moderate volume in the central and southern Plains, with a few higher quality at $64.25, feedlot sources said.

The bulk of Thursday's sales were steady with Wednesday, but up $1.00 from last week. An estimated 20,000 to 25,000 head sold in the Texas Panhandle/western Oklahoma area and about 30,000 in Kansas, sources in those areas said.
Owners had been asking $65.00 amid expectations sharply higher beef prices this week would lift fed cattle prices above $64.00, cattle feeders said.

Outlooks for $65.00 also had been inspired by active trading in Nebraska Tuesday at $105.00-$106.00 on a dressed basis, up $2-$3 from last week's top and $65.50, with a few at $66.50 on a live basis, up $1.50-$2.50, they said.
Weekly sales in Nebraska were estimated near 115,000 head, above and beyond estimated showlists of 85,000 to 90,000.
Optimisim among owners faded on talk this week's higher beef prices were topping and that beef demand was on the verge of slowing down.
Beef prices were sharply higher this week amid tight stocks and moderate demand from retailers ordering for Independence Day holiday features, market sources said.
